elements.content: MOF-based sensors capable of effectively and stably detecting toxic species in water have attracted huge attention in terms of improving environmental monitoring levels and water quality. Combining the flexibility of structure and modifying of pore surface, a multiwalled divider installation (MWDI) strategy is proposed and used for property enhancement. We herein report three metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) 1–3 based on a C 3 symmetry organic phosphonic ligand with topology increased from 3,6-connected to 3,8-connected. Among them, MOFs 1 and 2 with remaining binding sites and large pores display lower luminescence response to Co2+ than does the applying standard. Guided by the MWDI strategy, 3 with high rigid framework and triple molecular installer divided rhombic pore was achieved under top-down topological analysis as anticipated, which endows high sensitivity and rapid response to Co2+, contributed by the synergy from free activated sites and appropriate pore and molecular dividing effect. Particularly, the high stability of 3 in boiling solvent and acid/base solutions has been evidenced and explained by structural robustness and kinetic inertness. Moreover, 3 shows excellent detection ability toward trinitrophenol (TNP) over other aromatic analytes in water, attributing to the predomination of energy transfers. Of note is that the used framework can be in situ regenerated into a fresh one. That provides a promising strategy to prepare effective and economic luminescent sensors in a predictable way for property modification.

elements.content: With crises and accidents involving drinking water contamination happened increasingly, the demand for effective detection of toxic species from water sources is a much greater and the apprehension about human health and water quality spans the globe regions. Cobalt, as one of the essential trace elements, plays a crucial role in the metabolism and synthesis of hemoglobin, and it is also a main component of some biological compounds. Some pathological issues could be caused by deficiency of cobalt. However, it is also a noteworthy environmental contaminant, showing negative influence on the growth of crops. Similarly, apart from cobalt ions, trinitrophenol (TNP) is a common explosive extensively applied in dyes, the pharmaceutics, and leather industries and is also an unfriendly pollutant in watery environments due to the high toxicity and difficult degradation by nature once released to the environment. Compared with some traditional detection methods employed for sensing metal ions and aromatics, such as liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry, surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, and electrochemical methods, luminescence-based methods have received tremendous research enthusiasm owing to high sensitivity, low operational cost, ease of operation, and facile visualization.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

With crises and accidents involving drinking water contamination happened increasingly, the demand for effective detection of toxic species from water sources is a much greater and the apprehension about human health and water quality spans the globe regions. Cobalt, as one of the essential trace elements, plays a crucial role in the metabolism and synthesis of hemoglobin, and it is also a main component of some biological compounds. Some pathological issues could be caused by deficiency of cobalt. However, it is also a noteworthy environmental contaminant, showing negative influence on the growth of crops. Similarly, apart from cobalt ions, trinitrophenol (TNP) is a common explosive extensively applied in dyes, the pharmaceutics, and leather industries and is also an unfriendly pollutant in watery environments due to the high toxicity and difficult degradation by nature once released to the environment. Compared with some traditional detection methods employed for sensing metal ions and aromatics, such as liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry, surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, and electrochemical methods, luminescence-based methods have received tremendous research enthusiasm owing to high sensitivity, low operational cost, ease of operation, and facile visualization.

elements.content: As a class of newly developed multidimensional network crystalline solid materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are regarded as a favorable platform for sensing. The booming progress of MOFs in the application field is based on their tunable modular structure and variable topology, and in turn, propelling structural multiplicity into a higher level is the desired requirement for functionalization and efficiency. Although much contribution has been built by constructing luminescent MOFs for detecting metal ion and nitroaromatic pollutants, the mismatching between host structures with guest analytes and the deficiency of effective active sites may lead to lower detecting sensitivities and become the major limitations for their performance improvement. Besides, in the previous investigation of MOFs, the reports on detection involving water system and framework enabling regeneration are rare. These obstacles may greatly restrict its applied region in practical condition. Hence, to address the problems simultaneously by designing and synthesizing highly stable, pore space modified and recycled MOFs for more sensitive monitoring and sensing of these specific pollutants from water is quite important for homeland security, environmental safety, and human health.

Besides, in the previous investigation of MOFs, the reports on detection involving water system and framework enabling regeneration are rare. These obstacles may greatly restrict its applied region in practical condition. Hence, to address the problems simultaneously by designing and synthesizing highly stable, pore space modified and recycled MOFs for more sensitive monitoring and sensing of these specific pollutants from water is quite important for homeland security, environmental safety, and human health.

elements.content: In this contribution, we herein propose an approach to modify framework space by multiwalled divider installation (MWDI) strategy. At beginning, two metal organic frameworks (MOFs) 1 and 2 with 3,6-connected apo and pyr topology were constructed via C 3 asymmetric organic phosphonic ligand. To these two MOFs with remaining binding sites and large pores, their sensing performance for Co2+ cannot reach the applying standard. Under the guidance of the MWDI strategy, the additional size-matching molecular building pillars were installed in the host frameworks and synthesized 3 with cluster connectivity increase and triple-walled pillared divided rhombic porous framework, supported by top-down topological analysis. As expected, 3 shows high sensitivity and rapid response to Co2+; the influence of the accessibility of active sites and appropriate pore and molecular dividing effect were discussed systematically. Moreover, the framework of 3 maintains integrity in boiling solvent and diverse pH values aqueous solutions, and the explanation is well-established structurally and kinetically. On the basis of the good water stability and the superior Co2+ cation sensing ability of 3, detecting the trace amount of nitroaromatics in water were explored. It is noteworthy that 3 represents high quenching efficiency to trinitrophenol (TNP) with lower limit of detection, and the excellent detecting level can be retained after five recycles. The used framework can be reconstructed into a fresh one in situ successfully.

elements.content: Taking the functional performance and practical application for the sensing indicator into account, sensitivity and stability are two crucial aspects of measuring the performance of detection. In light of MOF-based sensors inherent structural character, the major limitations hindering their performance improvement are the mismatching between host pore structures with guest analytes and the lack of an effective active site. At the beginning, we chose tris­(para-carboxylphenyl) phosphine oxide (H3TPO), an aromatic multicarboxyl organic phosphonic C 3 symmetry ligand, which has proved a good candidate for detecting and sensing owing to the potential remaining active site with d10 metal salts and designed and synthesized MOFs 1 and 2. These two MOFs have large pore volume and uncoordinated active binding site; with regard to the sensing response to metal ion, there is still a gap between their detecting performance and the practical applied requirement. To address the issue of property enhancement, we introduce the MWDI from the optimizing the pore structures viewpoint. As mentioned, the following corresponding aspects have been expected: (1) The remaining PO group needs to be located into the framework and be directed to the inner of pores with appropriate volume. (2) The formation of installing the molecular building unit should be introduced into the framework. Herein, guided by the MWDI strategy, a top-down topological analysis method is applied to construct 3.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Functional Induced Multiwalled Divider Installation Design and Synthesis Strategy

Taking the functional performance and practical application for the sensing indicator into account, sensitivity and stability are two crucial aspects of measuring the performance of detection. In light of MOF-based sensors inherent structural character, the major limitations hindering their performance improvement are the mismatching between host pore structures with guest analytes and the lack of an effective active site. At the beginning, we chose tris(para-carboxylphenyl) phosphine oxide (H3TPO), an aromatic multicarboxyl organic phosphonic C 3 symmetry ligand, which has proved a good candidate for detecting and sensing owing to the potential remaining active site with d10 metal salts and designed and synthesized MOFs 1 and 2. These two MOFs have large pore volume and uncoordinated active binding site; with regard to the sensing response to metal ion, there is still a gap between their detecting performance and the practical applied requirement. To address the issue of property enhancement, we introduce the MWDI from the optimizing the pore structures viewpoint. As mentioned, the following corresponding aspects have been expected: (1) The remaining PO group needs to be located into the framework and be directed to the inner of pores with appropriate volume. (2) The formation of installing the molecular building unit should be introduced into the framework. Herein, guided by the MWDI strategy, a top-down topological analysis method is applied to construct 3.

elements.content: Initially, the possible and suitable topology with desired structural characters should be found out theoretically. Starting from the simplest binodal edge-transitive nets, owing to the geometrical morphology characteristic of H3TPO ligand itself and the functional requirement of remaining groups, we confirm binodal edge-transitive nets with a 3-connected node (, top). Naturally, our aim focuses on determining connectivity of secondary building units (SBUs). Herein, we reviewed the topologies of 1 and 2 (, middle) and analyzed and listed the nodes that can be assigned to SBUs in corresponding nets (, bottom). Through this top-down analysis, 12-connection with trinuclear metal cluster, the highest connectivity in reported SBUs, intrigues us for improving the robustness of MOFs. Furthermore, combining the MWDI strategy, six connection points are merged to two triple-walls and function as an 8-connected node. Thus, the new 3,8-connected network containing trinuclear metal cluster and H3TPO ligand becomes our target.

elements.content:
C 3 symmetry 3-connected linker H3TPO (top), binodal edge-transitive networks with 3-connected nodes (middle), and nodes assigned to secondary building units in corresponding nets (bottom).

After determination of the topology and the SBUs of our desired MOF, the next step is to consider the geometry details of each node and the possible kind of organic ligand installer. Due to the semirigid structural character and steric hindrance, the three benzene rings of H3TPO ligand are used to show large dihedral angle. Specifically, the tendency of these to be perpendicular to each other would maximize the freedom of PO groups and further increase the accessibility of the active site. Generally, the linear trinuclear SBUs are chosen because of the compatibility to the connectivity and multiple-wall dividing effect in the target network. With regard to the second linker with dividing function, setting the reported framework as reference, the N-donor auxiliary ligand is preferred. Hence, a pillar molecular building unit 4,4′-bipy is selected based on its size-matching features.

After determination of the topology and the SBUs of our desired MOF, the next step is to consider the geometry details of each node and the possible kind of organic ligand installer. Due to the semirigid structural character and steric hindrance, the three benzene rings of H3TPO ligand are used to show large dihedral angle. Specifically, the tendency of these to be perpendicular to each other would maximize the freedom of PO groups and further increase the accessibility of the active site. Generally, the linear trinuclear SBUs are chosen because of the compatibility to the connectivity and multiple-wall dividing effect in the target network. With regard to the second linker with dividing function, setting the reported framework as reference, the N-donor auxiliary ligand is preferred. Hence, a pillar molecular building unit 4,4'-bipy is selected based on its size-matching features.

elements.content: Herein, after accurately tuning the amounts and ratio of the reacting components, hydrothermal reactions of tris­(para-carboxylphenyl) phosphine oxide (H3TPO) and auxiliary ligand 4,4′-bipy with metal salts yielded single-crystals of 3 suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. As shown in Figure S11, the observation of slight blue shifts of carbonyl group characteristic IR vibration peaks in 1–3 proved the coordination interaction of carboxylate groups.

As shown in Figure S11, the observation of slight blue shifts of carbonyl group characteristic IR vibration peaks in 1-3 proved the coordination interaction of carboxylate groups.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that {[Zn­(HTPO)]·6H2O} n (1) crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbcn. The asymmetric unit contains one zinc atom and one HTPO2– ligand (Figure S1). The combination of 2 Zn­(II) atoms and 10 oxygen atoms forms a typical pillared paddlewheel-type Zn2(CO2)4O2 moiety SBU with the distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry, in which the equatorial plane are coordinated by four carboxyl oxygen from different HTPO2– ligands and axial positions are completed by phosphine oxides (Zn–O, 1.954–2.058 Å). Each pillared paddlewheel-type SBU in 1 is connected to six adjacent HTPO2– ligands and a 3D highly porous framework structure was constructed (a). Remarkably, uncoordinated carboxyl of HTPO2– ligands as the potential active binding group exist in 1; however, the strong intermolecular hydrogen bond is established between them with very close 1.827 Å distance (c). Along the a axis, one-dimensional open rhombic shape channels with size of 11.788 × 9.490 Å2 are observed (d). Topologically, the paddlewheel SBUs and HTPO2– ligands are regarded as 6-connected (Figure S2) and 3-connected nodes (e), respectively; the framework structure of 1 can be simplified as a 3,6-connected apo topology network. The effective free volume of 1 is 44.5% calculated by PLATON.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 1-3 

Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that {[Zn(HTPO)]⋅6H2O} n  (1) crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbcn. The asymmetric unit contains one zinc atom and one HTPO2- ligand (Figure S1). The combination of 2 Zn(II) atoms and 10 oxygen atoms forms a typical pillared paddlewheel-type Zn2(CO2)4O2 moiety SBU with the distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry, in which the equatorial plane are coordinated by four carboxyl oxygen from different HTPO2- ligands and axial positions are completed by phosphine oxides (Zn-O, 1.954-2.058 Å). Each pillared paddlewheel-type SBU in 1 is connected to six adjacent HTPO2- ligands and a 3D highly porous framework structure was constructed (a). Remarkably, uncoordinated carboxyl of HTPO2- ligands as the potential active binding group exist in 1; however, the strong intermolecular hydrogen bond is established between them with very close 1.827 Å distance (c). Along the a axis, one-dimensional open rhombic shape channels with size of 11.788 × 9.490 Å2 are observed (d). Topologically, the paddlewheel SBUs and HTPO2- ligands are regarded as 6-connected (Figure S2) and 3-connected nodes (e), respectively; the framework structure of 1 can be simplified as a 3,6-connected apo topology network. The effective free volume of 1 is 44.5% calculated by PLATON.

elements.content: To better evaluate and compare the impact of different active binding sites in framework structure and function, another framework 2 formulated as {H­[Zn3(OH) (TPO)2]·3DMF·2H2O} n was also prepared from Zn­(NO3)2 and H3TPO ligand. 2 crystallizes in the cubic space group Pa3̅ and features a trimetal Zn3O cluster based 3D 3,6-connected pyr network (g and S5). In the structure, there exists one third of crystallographically independent Zn atom in a tetrahedral coordination geometry (Figure S3a). Three Zn atoms connected with each other by μ3-OH group form a distorted octahedral shaped [Zn3(OH)­(CO2)6] SBU (Figure S3b), which is linked by three bidentate and monodentate bridging carboxylates below and above the Zn3O plane of SBU (b). As shown in f, there are a 1D square (11.059 × 11.705 Å2), rather than rhombic channels based on Zn­(II), and a ligand array along the c axis in the 3D framework of 2, in which owing to the long distance between phosphine oxide-O forms and Zn3 cluster the oxygens of PO groups still remain free-standing at the corner of the cavity instead of the wall of framework. For improving utilization of unoccupied void in space, two identical 3D pore framework structures interpenetrate each other (Figure S4). Overall, the main framework of 2 is similar to that of PCM-4; however, the absent coordinated water molecules surrounding the [Zn3(OH) (CO2)6] cluster in 2 may make the flexibility and function of PO group available. The total solvent-accessible volume of 2 is estimated by PLATON to be 46.8% of per unit cell after removing free solvent molecules, which is comparable to that of 1.

elements.content: Guided by the strategy of MWDI and the aforementioned topological analysis, we introduced the 4,4′-bipy as triple pillar molecule unit to divide the volume of pore. As we expected, 3D structure {[Cd1.5(TPO)­(bipy)1.5]·3H2O}2n (3) with three size-matching bipy molecules serving as the triple-wall divider and the free PO group toward channel centroid was prepared via hydrothermal from Cd­(OAc)2, tris­(para-carboxylphenyl) phosphine oxide, and 4,4′-bipy. A single-crystal X-ray analysis showed that 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c (Table S1). There are two categories of independent Cd­(II) ions; 1 TPO3– ligand, 1.5 bipy ligands, and 3 free water molecules appear in the asymmetric unit of 3 (Figure S6a). The adjacent linear trinuclear [Cd3(CO2)6N6] SBUs are connected into a 2D layer with a 11.694 Å atom-to-atom distance (Figure S7). Additionally, the chelating carboxyl groups extend the 2D layers into the 3D frameworks with the rhombic-shaped open channels from up and down directions. Along the b axis, the three 4,4′-bipy molecules served as the pillar-shaped bracket for supporting the 1D open channels, which not only increases the framework rigidity but also divides the large pores into same two segments (b). The cooperation of such channels and divider contributes to 17.5% solvent-accessible voids for the crystal volume, as calculated by PLATON. Topologically, each Cd3 SBU can be regarded as 8-connected node, and C 3-symmetric ligands serve as the 3-connected linkers (d). Thus, the 3D framework could be simplified by TOPOS to a 3,8-connected binodal net (c) with the point symbol of (4.52)2(42.510.612.7.83) being relative rare among transition metal MOFs.

elements.content: The PXRD patterns (Figure S12) confirmed the crystalline purity of as-synthesized 1–3. The determination of final chemical formulated based on the results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and element analysis (EA). As shown in Figure S13, the TGA curves of 1 displays that a weight loss of 17.13% (calcd 18.57%) which initially corresponds to removal of six H2O molecules within the temperature range of 25–301 °C; the framework remains intact up to 310 °C. 2 shows the solvent removal of two water followed by three DMF molecules (25–210 °C) with the weight loss of 19.10% (calcd 18.46%), and the framework remains stable to above 375 °C. The host framework of 3 is thermally stabilized up to 410 °C after the water molecules removed. The remaining residue of 1–3 corresponds to metal oxides, respectively.

elements.content: The luminescent spectra are recorded and shown in Figure S14, the luminescent emissions of 1–3 are mainly located at 393–427 nm blue-light region upon excitation at ∼360 nm; correspondingly, the Commission Internacionale d’Eclairage (CIE) coordinates codes are (0.18, 0.12) for 1, (0.17, 0.11) for 2, and (0.17, 0.15) for 3. Owing to the similarity of emission with free H3TPO ligand (λmax = 406 nm), the emission bands of 1–3 can be tentatively ascribed to the intraligand π* → π transition. Furthermore, we have measured quantum yields and lifetimes of 1–3 and ligands. Compared to those of the ligands, the quantum yields of 1–3 are much higher, and the lifetimes are similar, which may be due to the fact that the coordination interactions between ligands and the metal center increase the rigidity of ligand, reduce the loss of energy via thermal vibration decay, and enhance luminescence efficiency. To examine the potential capacity of 1–3 to detect a trace amount of metal ions, dispersed solutions of 1–3 were formed by an ultrasound method, and a solution of M­(NO3) x (4 mM) (M = Na+, Ag+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Al3+, and Gd3+) was added into the above suspension. Interestingly, upon the addition of M­(NO3) x solution into the 1–3 suspension, 1 has no significant response in emission. However, 2 and 3 exhibit luminescent quenching effect in response to Co2+ ion, and the quenching efficiency of 3 is significantly better than that of 2 ().
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Behavior and Detection of Metal Cation

The luminescent spectra are recorded and shown in Figure S14, the luminescent emissions of 1-3 are mainly located at 393-427 nm blue-light region upon excitation at ~360 nm; correspondingly, the Commission Internacionale d'Eclairage (CIE) coordinates codes are (0.18, 0.12) for 1, (0.17, 0.11) for 2, and (0.17, 0.15) for 3. Owing to the similarity of emission with free H3TPO ligand (λmax = 406 nm), the emission bands of 1-3 can be tentatively ascribed to the intraligand π* → π transition. Furthermore, we have measured quantum yields and lifetimes of 1-3 and ligands. Compared to those of the ligands, the quantum yields of 1-3 are much higher, and the lifetimes are similar, which may be due to the fact that the coordination interactions between ligands and the metal center increase the rigidity of ligand, reduce the loss of energy via thermal vibration decay, and enhance luminescence efficiency. To examine the potential capacity of 1-3 to detect a trace amount of metal ions, dispersed solutions of 1-3 were formed by an ultrasound method, and a solution of M(NO3) x  (4 mM) (M = Na+, Ag+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Al3+, and Gd3+) was added into the above suspension. Interestingly, upon the addition of M(NO3) x  solution into the 1-3 suspension, 1 has no significant response in emission. However, 2 and 3 exhibit luminescent quenching effect in response to Co2+ ion, and the quenching efficiency of 3 is significantly better than that of 2 ().

elements.content: The luminescent quenching efficiencies of 2 and 3 in response to Co2+ can be quantitatively explained in the concentration range of 0.02–0.2 mM by the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation: I 0/I = K SV[Q] + 1, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after adding Co­(NO3)2, respectively, [Q] is the Co­(NO3)2 molar concentration, and K SV is the quenching constant. As illustrated in b, for 2, the SV curve for Co2+ is nearly linear at the concentration range (R 2 = 0.998) with a K SV value of 7.18 × 103 M–1. Furthermore, on the basis of the confidence level parameter (k), the standard deviation for five repeated luminescent measurements values of blank solutions (σ), and the sensitivity of the luminescence peak toward Co­(NO3)2 concentration (S), the limit of detection (LOD) for 2 toward Co2+ was calculated to be 1.91 μM (Table S4), following the equation: LOD = k × σ/S. In comparison with 2, MOF 3 dispersed in H2O solution processes the turn-off sensing ability in respone to Co2+ with higher quenching efficiency (K SV = 1.60 × 104 M–1) and improved LOD calculated to be 0.31 μM (d, Table S5), which is far below the maximum permitted level of 1.7 μM of groundwater quality criterion defined by the Department of Environmental Protection of New Jersey and basically meets the requirements of application for Co2+-binding chemosensors.

elements.content: The time-response characteristic of 3 toward Co2+ was investigated via measuring the emission of suspension solution of 3 in H2O solution of 20 μM Co2+. Figure S16a shows that with increasing interaction time, the luminescence intensity continuously decreased. Nearly half quenching of emission for Co2+-incorporated MOF 3 can be observed when treatment time is 5 min, and within 10 min, the turn-off response reaches 80% compared with that of pristine sample (Figure S16b). At times over 1 h, the luminescence intensity value remains constant. The fast and high-efficiency quenching response and the low detection concentration for Co2+ allowed us to identify conveniently the existence of trace quantities of Co2+ in water.

elements.content: In general, the luminescence quenching mechanisms of 2 and 3 toward Co2+ could mainly be attributed to (1) the structure decomposition induced by the metal ions; (2) ion exchange between the framework metal centers and the metal ions; and (3) strong interaction between metal ions and framework. The PXRD patterns of the 2-Co2+ and 3-Co2+ are similar to each other (Figure S17), which indicates the main frameworks of 2 and 3 are maintained. Furthermore, inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis was applied to 2, 2-Co2+, 3, and 3-Co2+, and the results (Table S3) show that Zn content in 2 (14.09%) and 2-Co2+ (13.92%) and Cd contents in 3 (19.11%) and 3-Co2+ (18.95%) are close in each case, which illustrates that Zn2+/Cd2+ in the framework was not exchanged by Co2+ during the quenching process. Thus, the collapse of the MOF frameworks and ion exchange mechanisms were ruled out, and combining interaction between Co2+ and framework was confirmed. Meanwhile, the intensities of the IR curves (Figure S18) for 2-Co2+ and 3-Co2+ at some peaks are relatively weaker than those of 2 and 3, which are also primarily due to Co2+ combination. In addition, the maximum overlap between absorption band of Co2+ and emission spectra of 2 and 3 (Figure S19) verifies the intermolecular energy transfer process. That is, the sensing of 2 and 3 toward Co2+ were attributed to the combination between Co2+ and MOF, and the induced intermolecular energy transfer leads to quenching luminescence.

elements.content: Nevertheless, taking the vertical comparison of 1–3 structures, there arise two questionable points. One of them is that MOFs 1–3 all have remaining sites in their corresponding structure, but the quenching phenomena resulting from binding of metal ion did not happen in 1. The other is that the same kind of binding sites (PO) undergo different sensing activities in 2 and 3; the surrounding microenvironment of the sensing site is the most significant difference among sensing process of these three MOFs. Thus, it is reasonable to propose that the efficient binding Co­(II) may result from the following aspects: (1) Accessibility of activated sites: Looking deeper inside 1, the uncoordinated site is imposed by the strong O–H···O hydrogen interactions which show the negative impact during the binding process. We assumed that the restriction of interaction could be broken and that Co2+ would be bound or join the formation of another new crystal phase if a more powerful outside force was applied. This is proved by the hydrothermal reaction of the Co­(NO3)2 with 1 in 120 °C. As shown in Figure S20, the crystal color changes to purple, and absorption intensity of reacting liquor decreases obviously. (2) Suitable size and shape of pore: Obviously, the cavity could provide an opportunity or pathway for the analyte to interact with the host framework. A suitably sized cavity, which plays a key role for binding based sensing process, can ensure the accessibility and enhance the efficiency simultaneously. Furthermore, a suitably shaped one will have a positive effect on metal cation binding behavior. In our work, the separated rhombus pore is more beneficial to the binding process and quenching response, supported by comparison with the sensing performances of 1–3. Individually, the uncoordinated PO groups excluding the restriction of weak interaction and directing toward the inner pores, along with the triple-wall installed rhombus pore, may endow the framework of 3 a higher sensing ability. That is, synergetic interaction from free active sites and a refined cavity indeed make huge contribution to the high and quick sensing response toward Co­(II) by 3 ().

Framework Stability and Kinetics Explanation

Retention of structural integrity after detection to target analytes in intermediate is an important indicator or the basis of any material that might be considered for industrial applications. As such, the chemical stability of 3 is evaluated and investigated. Herein, the single-crystals of 3 have the good humid resistance property and can remain unchanged in air for a long time. Furthermore, to investigate the water, organic solvent, and even acidic or basic resistance property, 3 was examined after being soaked in aqueous solutions, a variety of organic solvents (DMF, CH3CN, CH3OH, THF, or CHCl3), and pH 2–10 aqueous solutions at room temperature for 24 h. As shown in , powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns remained almost intact under the treatment of not only water and diverse solvents but also HCl or NaOH aqueous solutions, suggesting that crystal structure and crystallinity of 3 could be kept and that no phase transition or framework collapse occurs.

elements.content: The high solvent and acid-/base-proof stabilities of 3 may be attributed to the tuning of structural features as predesigned by MWDI strategy. Introducing the secondary ligand plays the crucial role in stability. First, the strength of coordination bond surrounding the metal cluster is improved. From the MOFs construction perspective, the pK a of the organic ligand (Lewis base) have a non-negligible impact on the strength of metal–ligand bonds. Choosing the 4,4′-bipyridine with higher pK a (pyridine, pK a = 5.3) as auxiliary ligand could increase the strength of metal–ligand bonds and facilitate the construction of the porous materials with exceptional stability. Second, the connectivity of SBUs is increased. The higher connecting manner of metal cluster SBUs can prevent the attack of guest water, other solvent molecules, or even acid/base and further restrain the dissociation of coordination bond. Hence, the strategy of MWDI is effective and worthy to be conducted in constructing stable MOFs. Eventually, the size-matched triple-pillared support not only contributes to dividing effect but also benefits the robustness of the architecture.

elements.content: Theoretically, the above-mentioned critical aspects could be favored and explained from the kinetic perspectives as well. It is well-known that the decomposition process of MOFs in solution could be understood as a reversible substitution reaction, during which coordination moieties are replaced by host molecules or ions to generate the free or partly free ligands (so-called coordination defects). Regarding the SBUs as the leaving group, when displacement of one coordination site happens, the SBUs might be restricted via other linked sites of coordination moiety and keep around or temporarily hang out. The high “effective concentration” around the coordination defects generated by the restriction effect would accelerate the rate of the reverse reaction to reconnect the dissociated site to the ligand and repair the structure. Naturally, the conclusion can be drawn that SBUs with higher connectivities will be stiffer and that MOFs constructed by them are more stable. Hence, the 12-connected coordination moieties functioning as 3,8-connected SBUs is one key factor to high stability of 3. Besides, activation energy is another critical factor to evaluate how easily the chemical reactions can occur. Specific to the decomposition of MOFs, we use the simple model to elaborate visually. First, for comparison conveniently, two simplifications have been done. As shown in a, the two ideally rigid isostructural MOFs only differing in the length of C 3 symmetry ligand, namely, MOF-S (deep blue) and MOF-S′ (light blue), are simplified as the connection of dot and line. The deformation of ligands coordinated to SBUs is simplified to the bent form in transition states. Then, the bent displacement at terminals of ligand (d) is generated and starts to increase with the dissociation. When the distances are equal (d = d′) for these two MOFs (a, bottom), longer linker l takes a smaller angle θ compared to that of shorter linker l′, which would result in less strain to the remaining coordination sites on the linker and a lower activation energy (b,c, showing the activation energy of MOF-S and MOF-S′ schematically). As a consequence, MOF-S′ with the shorter ligand is more inert and stable. Hence, the fact that H3TPO is the shortest C 3 organic phosphonic carboxylic acid ligand in reported relevant MOFs supports the kinetic stability of 3 as well.

elements.content: Inspired by the good water stability of 3, the superior metal cation sensing ability along with the harm and negative effect of aromatics in environment, security, and body health comprehensively, its application concerning the monitoring the trace amount of aromatics in water were explored. For this purpose, luminescent titration measurements were performed by the gradual addition of 5 mM water of the analytes to well-dispersed suspensions of 3 in water. The aromatics analytes we chose to check here include trinitrophenol (TNP), 2,6-dinitrotoluene (2,6-DNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), nitrobenzene (NB), benzoic acid (BC), methylbenzene (MB), phenol (PHL), chlorobenzene (CB), and benzene (BZ). The luminescent quenching phenomenon happed after adding the same amount of analytes (30 μL) with different extent. The quenching efficiency was calculated via the equation (I 0 – I)/I 0 × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of 3 before and after the addition of the analyte, respectively. As shown in c and S21, the most sensitive and significant quenching of the luminescence intensity of 3 has been realized after addition of 30 μL of 5 mM TNP solution (the nearly 92%). Comparably, the quenching effect of 3 for other aromatic analytes is much lower, and the lowest detecting efficiency was observed for MB. The quenching efficiencies by all the selected analytes is in the following order: TNP ≫ NB > 2,4-DNT > 2,6-DNT > BC > BZ > PHL > CB > MB.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Nitroaromatics

Inspired by the good water stability of 3, the superior metal cation sensing ability along with the harm and negative effect of aromatics in environment, security, and body health comprehensively, its application concerning the monitoring the trace amount of aromatics in water were explored. For this purpose, luminescent titration measurements were performed by the gradual addition of 5 mM water of the analytes to well-dispersed suspensions of 3 in water. The aromatics analytes we chose to check here include trinitrophenol (TNP), 2,6-dinitrotoluene (2,6-DNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), nitrobenzene (NB), benzoic acid (BC), methylbenzene (MB), phenol (PHL), chlorobenzene (CB), and benzene (BZ). The luminescent quenching phenomenon happed after adding the same amount of analytes (30 μL) with different extent. The quenching efficiency was calculated via the equation (I 0 - I)/I 0 × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of 3 before and after the addition of the analyte, respectively. As shown in c and S21, the most sensitive and significant quenching of the luminescence intensity of 3 has been realized after addition of 30 μL of 5 mM TNP solution (the nearly 92%). Comparably, the quenching effect of 3 for other aromatic analytes is much lower, and the lowest detecting efficiency was observed for MB. The quenching efficiencies by all the selected analytes is in the following order: TNP ≫ NB > 2,4-DNT > 2,6-DNT > BC > BZ > PHL > CB > MB.

elements.content: To comprehend the different sensing ability of 3 for aromatic complexes and the superior behavior for TNP, the luminescent emission spectra were collected by a gradual addition of analytes. Herein, with the help of SV equation, the diversity in quenching efficiency can also be clearly interpreted. Similar to those in sensing Co2+, the SV plot for TNP is also nearly linear at low concentration and deviates from linearity upon incremental addition of TNP (Figures S22–S30). However, for the other analytes, the linear relationships were embodied in SV plots over same testing concentration range (d). Accordingly, K SV and the LOD of 3 toward TNP are estimated to be 2.4 × 105 M–1 and 15 ppb, respectively (Table S6). Compared to that of most traditional MOF-based sensors, Ksv value for TNP is larger and reaches a superior level, as summarized in Table S7. It is noteworthy that a large contribution to sensing and detecting nitroaromatics relied on luminescent quenching behavior. Nevertheless, the majority of reports are based on organic solvent detecting systems such as CH3OH, C2H5OH, DMF, and CH3CN. Only few samples can display good sensing ability toward TNP in water. The low LOD, high quenching constant, and the aqueous phase detection for TNP illustrate that 3 has a supersensitive potential to detect TNP.

elements.content: With regard to the observed luminescence attenuation and extraordinary TNP-sensing ability of 3, the explanation based on the electron-transfer and resonance energy-transfer mechanisms have been well-established. From the electron-transfer perspective, generally, the conduction band (CB) energies of electron-rich MOFs are higher than the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO) of analytes. Upon excitation by the ultraviolet light, the excited electrons transfer from the CB of MOFs to the LUMOs. Furthermore, as the driving force, the larger the energy difference, the more effective the luminescence quenching. The high effective luminescence quenching of 3 toward TNP is in good accordance with the lowest LUMO energy among the testing analytes ( and S32 and Table S9); the resonance energy transfer mechanism is responsible for the discordance in the order of observed quenching efficiency and calculated the LUMO energies of analytes. It is known that the energy transfer process can happen under the condition that the luminescent emission overlaps with the UV absorption, and the overlap extent determines the transfer effectiveness. Hence, the UV–vis spectra of analytes were recorded. As shown in Figure S33, the results show that the absorption band of TNP exhibits a maximum degree of overlap with the emission band of 3, in contrast to the slight or even no overlap of other analytes, which accounts for the high effective quenching performance of 3 to TNP.
elements.clean_text: With regard to the observed luminescence attenuation and extraordinary TNP-sensing ability of 3, the explanation based on the electron-transfer and resonance energy-transfer mechanisms have been well-established. From the electron-transfer perspective, generally, the conduction band (CB) energies of electron-rich MOFs are higher than the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO) of analytes. Upon excitation by the ultraviolet light, the excited electrons transfer from the CB of MOFs to the LUMOs. Furthermore, as the driving force, the larger the energy difference, the more effective the luminescence quenching. The high effective luminescence quenching of 3 toward TNP is in good accordance with the lowest LUMO energy among the testing analytes ( and S32 and Table S9); the resonance energy transfer mechanism is responsible for the discordance in the order of observed quenching efficiency and calculated the LUMO energies of analytes. It is known that the energy transfer process can happen under the condition that the luminescent emission overlaps with the UV absorption, and the overlap extent determines the transfer effectiveness. Hence, the UV-vis spectra of analytes were recorded. As shown in Figure S33, the results show that the absorption band of TNP exhibits a maximum degree of overlap with the emission band of 3, in contrast to the slight or even no overlap of other analytes, which accounts for the high effective quenching performance of 3 to TNP.

elements.content: Schematic demonstrating the possible pathway for electron transfer from 3 to aromatic analytes.

elements.content: The results also illustrate that the energy transfer is more dominant between these two mechanisms, which is supported by the different quenching responses toward BC and NB. For them, the electron-transfer process is comparable because of the close LUMO levels, so the greater quenching effect toward NB stems from the energy-transfer process because of larger degree of overlap. Moreover, the electron transfer is a short-range process; only direct interaction with analytes would produce the luminescence quenching effect. Instead, like energy transfer, the interactions over the surrounding MOF host frameworks will be permitted by this long-range process, increasing the quenching effect of 3. With regard to the small quenching effect of 3 after gradual addition of electron-rich aromatics, the solvent cage effect would facilitate the luminescence quenching process of 3 due to the surrounding solvents environment in suspension. It is generally believed that the conjugated aromatics in excited states have a larger dipole moment than that in the ground states. Addition of electron-rich aromatics might reduce the total polarity of the whole dispersing system, leading to decrease of luminescent intensity.

elements.content: In addition to the two mechanisms mentioned above, the phenomenon of the SV plot for TNP obviously deviating from linearity at higher concentration suggests that the dynamic quenching caused by collisional encounter between the luminophores of the MOFs and TNP may appear in the process. The dynamic quenching process can be confirmed by change of the luminescent lifetimes. As shown in Figure S34, the luminescent lifetime of 3 is shortened from 8.57 to 7.53 μs after the TNP molecules are added in the range of 0–0.0125 mM, thus verifying the existence of the dynamic quenching process. Hence, the overall SV plot could be modified and defined as I 0/I = (K D[Q] + 1)­(K S[Q] + 1), where K D and K S represent the dynamic quenching and the static quenching constants, respectively. In the range of low TNP concentration, K D K S[Q]2 could be neglected, and the overall SV equation could be simplified as I 0/I = (K S + K D)­[Q] + 1. As illustrated in Figure S35, according to the SV equation of τ0/τ = K D[Q] + 1, where τ0 and τ are the lifetimes at the initial and the concentration of [Q], respectively, the lifetime SV plot can be curve-fitted to τ0/τ = 12 022 M–1[TNP] + 0.998. The static and dynamic quenching constants are calculated to be 2.28 × 105 and 1.20× 104 M–1, respectively. Comparably, the SV plots for other analytes show a linear relationship, which suggests that their moderate quenching would not be affected via the dynamic quenching. Consequently, combining the electron-transfer, resonance energy-transfer, and the dynamic quenching mechanisms caused by collisional encounter between MOFs and the TNP, the selectivity and sensitivity of luminescent detection of TNP is significantly enhanced.

elements.content: As mentioned, 3 displays high effective luminescence quenching for TNP, which means that 3 is a good candidate as a luminescence indicator for aromatic complexes. Can this high quenching efficiency be retained after serval cycles of reuse? For this purpose, 3 was recovered from the used solution by centrifugation and after washing with water for serval times. Gratifyingly, the recovered sample of 3 can be reused for at least five cycles after washing via water with the sensing activity being maintained (a). PXRD patterns of the recovered sample after five usage cycles pointed out that the structure of 3 is basically maintained (b).

elements.content: Notwithstanding the reusability of 3, its detection activity is reduced after more multiple cycles. Can the used 3 be reconstructed into a fresh one? If this is feasible, then the cost would be reduced, and the applied value would increase simultaneously. Motivated by the reversibility of coordination bond theoretically, reconstruction of the used framework into a fresh one is worth trying. After some attempts, in situ reconstructed fresh 3 has been realized via hydrothermally reacting used 3 powder in filtrated mother liquor at 160 °C for 5 days (Figure S36). Thereby, the cost of nitroaromatic-sensing indicator is highly reduced economically and strategically. As far as we know, reconstruction of used detectors into fresh ones has been rarely reported.

elements.content: Two luminescent porous MOFs with 3,6-connected apo and pyr topologies were initially rationally developed for sensing. On the basis of their lower luminescent quenching performance with regard to Co2+ and the purpose of functional improvement, 3,8-connected 3 with triple-wall divider, guided by MWDI strategy, was achieved via top-down topological analysis. As expected, 3 shows high sensitivity and rapid response to Co2+, and the synergy from free activated sites and appropriate pore and molecular dividing effect are responsible for this. Particularly, the excellent stability of 3 has been shown under boiling solvent and acidic/basic conditions, and explanation has been done structurally and kinetically. Moreover, 3 displays excellent detection ability toward TNP over other aromatic analytes, and in situ reconstruction of used framework into a fresh one can be realized. The MWDI strategy endows a facile way not only to fine-tune MOFs toward high stability but also to precisely modify pore space to improve sensing ability.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two luminescent porous MOFs with 3,6-connected apo and pyr topologies were initially rationally developed for sensing. On the basis of their lower luminescent quenching performance with regard to Co2+ and the purpose of functional improvement, 3,8-connected 3 with triple-wall divider, guided by MWDI strategy, was achieved via top-down topological analysis. As expected, 3 shows high sensitivity and rapid response to Co2+, and the synergy from free activated sites and appropriate pore and molecular dividing effect are responsible for this. Particularly, the excellent stability of 3 has been shown under boiling solvent and acidic/basic conditions, and explanation has been done structurally and kinetically. Moreover, 3 displays excellent detection ability toward TNP over other aromatic analytes, and in situ reconstruction of used framework into a fresh one can be realized. The MWDI strategy endows a facile way not only to fine-tune MOFs toward high stability but also to precisely modify pore space to improve sensing ability.

elements.content: The crystal data of 1–3 were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0. 71073 Å) at room temperature. The structures of 1–3 were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software. Anisotropic thermal parameters are refined to all of the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were held in calculated ideal positions on carbon atoms, and oxygen atoms in ligands were directly included in the molecular formula on water molecules. −OH groups of the Zn­(II)-based clusters in 2 were not added but calculated into molecular formula of the crystal data. For the highly disordered nature of the solvents in 1 and 2, these could not be finely made out in the refinement. Thus, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was applied to remove the diffraction contributed from the highly disordered guest molecules. The SQUEEZE result is appended as a CIF file. The chemical formulas were determined by the combination of single-crystal data, TGA results, and elemental analysis. CCDC 1536521, 1536522, and 1536523 contain the crystallographic data of 1–3. These data can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/ deposit. The details of structural refinement can be found in Table S1; selected bond lengths and bond angles of 1–3 can be found in Tables S11–S13.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

The crystal data of 1-3 were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0. 71073 Å) at room temperature. The structures of 1-3 were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software. Anisotropic thermal parameters are refined to all of the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were held in calculated ideal positions on carbon atoms, and oxygen atoms in ligands were directly included in the molecular formula on water molecules. -OH groups of the Zn(II)-based clusters in 2 were not added but calculated into molecular formula of the crystal data. For the highly disordered nature of the solvents in 1 and 2, these could not be finely made out in the refinement. Thus, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was applied to remove the diffraction contributed from the highly disordered guest molecules. The SQUEEZE result is appended as a CIF file. The chemical formulas were determined by the combination of single-crystal data, TGA results, and elemental analysis. CCDC 1536521, 1536522, and 1536523 contain the crystallographic data of 1-3. These data can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/ deposit. The details of structural refinement can be found in Table S1; selected bond lengths and bond angles of 1-3 can be found in Tables S11-S13.

elements.content: For the luminescence quenching measurements from metal ions, a typical experimental procedure was set up. Crystalline samples of 1–3 (2 mg) were finely ground and added to a vial containing deionized water (2 mL), followed by ultrasonication treatment for 30 min, forming a suspension solution. An aqueous solution (4 mM) of metal ion M­(NO3) x (M = Na+, Ag+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Al3+, and Gd3+) was added to the above suspension solution to form the metal ion incorporated MOF suspension for the luminescence studies. To have access to the relationship between quenching efficiency of 2 and 3 and Co2+ ion concentration, the luminescence emissions of 2 and 3 suspension solutions were measured after incremental addition of freshly prepared metal ion aqueous solutions (10 μL addition each time) upon excitation at 360 nm. Time-response luminescence emission of 3 was measured for 3-Co2+ obtained through adding 0.2 mM Co2+ aqueous solution in suspension solution of 3 for different times.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Measurements

For the luminescence quenching measurements from metal ions, a typical experimental procedure was set up. Crystalline samples of 1-3 (2 mg) were finely ground and added to a vial containing deionized water (2 mL), followed by ultrasonication treatment for 30 min, forming a suspension solution. An aqueous solution (4 mM) of metal ion M(NO3) x  (M = Na+, Ag+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Al3+, and Gd3+) was added to the above suspension solution to form the metal ion incorporated MOF suspension for the luminescence studies. To have access to the relationship between quenching efficiency of 2 and 3 and Co2+ ion concentration, the luminescence emissions of 2 and 3 suspension solutions were measured after incremental addition of freshly prepared metal ion aqueous solutions (10 μL addition each time) upon excitation at 360 nm. Time-response luminescence emission of 3 was measured for 3-Co2+ obtained through adding 0.2 mM Co2+ aqueous solution in suspension solution of 3 for different times.

elements.content: Similarly, in an aromatic analyte detection experiment, the finely ground powder sample of 3 (2 mg) was immersed in 2 mL of deionized water and ultrasonicated for 30 min to form a stable suspension solution. The luminescence upon excitation at 360 nm of the obtained suspension of 3 was recorded after addition of 30 μL of TNP, 2,6-DNT, 2,4-DNT, NB, BC, MB, PHL, CB, and BZ aromatic analytes. The luminescence quenching efficiency of 3 as a function of the concentration of aromatic analytes was evaluated via measuring the luminescence of aromatic analytes incorporated MOF suspension obtained after increasing additions of aromatic analyte solutions (5 mM, 5 μL addition each time) in 2 mL of MOF suspension. After each addition, the luminescence of the suspension was monitored (Figures S22–S30).

The luminescence quenching efficiency of 3 as a function of the concentration of aromatic analytes was evaluated via measuring the luminescence of aromatic analytes incorporated MOF suspension obtained after increasing additions of aromatic analyte solutions (5 mM, 5 μL addition each time) in 2 mL of MOF suspension. After each addition, the luminescence of the suspension was monitored (Figures S22-S30).

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (120.0 mg, 0.40 mmol) and H3TPO (40.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (2.0 mL), H2O (2.0 mL) and ethanol (1.0 mL) mixed solvent and transferred to a 20.0 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel reaction vessel, which was heated at 85 °C for 5 days in an oven. Cd(OAc)2⋅2H2O (52.0 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3TPO (40.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 4,4'-bipy (16.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in H2O (5.0 mL) and transferred to a 20.0 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel reaction vessel, which was heated at 160 °C for 5 days in an oven. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting colorless block crystals of 3 were harvested by filtration, washed with ethanol, and then dried in air (yield, 61%, based on H3TPO). Anal. cln_elements.content:
Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that {[Zn­(HTPO)]·6H2O} n (1) crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbcn. The asymmetric unit contains one zinc atom and one HTPO2– ligand (Figure S1). The combination of 2 Zn­(II) atoms and 10 oxygen atoms forms a typical pillared paddlewheel-type Zn2(CO2)4O2 moiety SBU with the distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry, in which the equatorial plane are coordinated by four carboxyl oxygen from different HTPO2– ligands and axial positions are completed by phosphine oxides (Zn–O, 1.954–2.058 Å). Each pillared paddlewheel-type SBU in 1 is connected to six adjacent HTPO2– ligands and a 3D highly porous framework structure was constructed (a). Remarkably, uncoordinated carboxyl of HTPO2– ligands as the potential active binding group exist in 1; however, the strong intermolecular hydrogen bond is established between them with very close 1.827 Å distance (c). Along the a axis, one-dimensional open rhombic shape channels with size of 11.788 × 9.490 Å2 are observed (d). Topologically, the paddlewheel SBUs and HTPO2– ligands are regarded as 6-connected (Figure S2) and 3-connected nodes (e), respectively; the framework structure of 1 can be simplified as a 3,6-connected apo topology network. The effective free volume of 1 is 44.5% calculated by PLATON.

The PXRD patterns (Figure S12) confirmed the crystalline purity of as-synthesized 1–3. The determination of final chemical formulated based on the results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and element analysis (EA). As shown in Figure S13, the TGA curves of 1 displays that a weight loss of 17.13% (calcd 18.57%) which initially corresponds to removal of six H2O molecules within the temperature range of 25–301 °C; the framework remains intact up to 310 °C. 2 shows the solvent removal of two water followed by three DMF molecules (25–210 °C) with the weight loss of 19.10% (calcd 18.46%), and the framework remains stable to above 375 °C. The host framework of 3 is thermally stabilized up to 410 °C after the water molecules removed. The remaining residue of 1–3 corresponds to metal oxides, respectively.
